document_metadata.description: Heme BEL model is a disease model based on Biological Expression Language (BEL) containing the core mechanisms of heme as modulator in Hemolytic diseases such as sickle-cell anemia, beta-thalassemia, malaria and autoimmune hemolytic anemia.
document_metadata.name: heme_26675351.bel

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: Sickle cell disease (SCD) and malaria are paradigmatic hemolytic disorders, in which alteration in the structure of red blood cells (RBCs) leads to the release of Hb and heme into the circulation.

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: Sickle cell disease (SCD) and malaria are paradigmatic hemolytic disorders, in which alteration in the structure of red blood cells (RBCs) leads to the release of Hb and heme into the circulation.

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: Sickle cell disease (SCD) and malaria are paradigmatic hemolytic disorders, in which alteration in the structure of red blood cells (RBCs) leads to the release of Hb and heme into the circulation.

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: This is the case in a mouse model of SCD, which is hallmarked by hemolysis, increased circulating Hb/heme, and low levels of Hp and Hx and shows elevated hepatic macrophage iron levels and M1 polarization.

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: Sickle cell disease (SCD) and malaria are paradigmatic hemolytic disorders, in which alteration in the structure of red blood cells (RBCs) leads to the release of Hb and heme into the circulation.

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: Within cells, heme is catabolized by the activity of heme oxygenases (inducible HO-1 and constitutive HO-2) into iron, carbon monoxide, and biliverdin.

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: Within cells, heme is catabolized by the activity of heme oxygenases (inducible HO-1 and constitutive HO-2) into iron, carbon monoxide, and biliverdin.

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: Within cells, heme is catabolized by the activity of heme oxygenases (inducible HO-1 and constitutive HO-2) into iron, carbon monoxide, and biliverdin.

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: Consistently, CD11b cells (granulocytes and monocytes) and iron-rich cells (macrophages) isolated from heme-treated Hx-null mice show a higher heme content and increased mRNA and protein expression of HO-1, Lferritin, and Fpn (Figure 1B-G) and elevated mRNA levels of the proinflammatory cytokine IL-6 ( Figure 1H).

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: Consistently, CD11b cells (granulocytes and monocytes) and iron-rich cells (macrophages) isolated from heme-treated Hx-null mice show a higher heme content and increased mRNA and protein expression of HO-1, Lferritin, and Fpn (Figure 1B-G) and elevated mRNA levels of the proinflammatory cytokine IL-6 ( Figure 1H).

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: Consistently, CD11b cells (granulocytes and monocytes) and iron-rich cells (macrophages) isolated from heme-treated Hx-null mice show a higher heme content and increased mRNA and protein expression of HO-1, Lferritin, and Fpn (Figure 1B-G) and elevated mRNA levels of the proinflammatory cytokine IL-6 ( Figure 1H).

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: In addition, we observed increased ROS production ( Figure 2I; supplemental Figure 2), as well as an enhanced expression of IL-6 and TNFα in cells treated with heme-albumin compared with heme-Hx (Figure 2J-K).

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: In addition, we observed increased ROS production ( Figure 2I; supplemental Figure 2), as well as an enhanced expression of IL-6 and TNFα in cells treated with heme-albumin compared with heme-Hx (Figure 2J-K).

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: Likewise, heme and FeNTA treatment causes the induction of the M1 markers MHCII, CD86, CD14, TNFα, IL-6, and IL1β and a decrease in the M2 markers CD206, IL-10, and Arginase-1 (the last with FeNTA only) in M0 BMDMs (Figure 3A; supplemental Figures 5, 6A, and 7).

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: In addition, we observed increased ROS production ( Figure 2I; supplemental Figure 2), as well as an enhanced expression of IL-6 and TNFα in cells treated with heme-albumin compared with heme-Hx (Figure 2J-K).

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: Likewise, heme and FeNTA treatment causes the induction of the M1 markers MHCII, CD86, CD14, TNFα, IL-6, and IL1β and a decrease in the M2 markers CD206, IL-10, and Arginase-1 (the last with FeNTA only) in M0 BMDMs (Figure 3A; supplemental Figures 5, 6A, and 7).

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: Importantly, 15 hours after heme injection, hepatic macrophages showed iron deposition (data not shown) and an increased expression of the M1 markers MHCII and CD86 and reduced levels of the M2 markers CD206 and Arginase-1 compared with nontreated mice.

links.evidence: Likewise, splenic macrophages from heme-treated mice show increased expression of CD86 and reduced levels of CD206 and Arginase-1 (Figure 3D).

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: This is the case in a mouse model of SCD, which is hallmarked by hemolysis, increased circulating Hb/heme, and low levels of Hp and Hx and shows elevated hepatic macrophage iron levels and M1 polarization.

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: Importantly, by scavenging free heme, Hx prevents heme-induced M1 macrophage polarization and thus avoids both TLR4 activation and ROS formation.

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: Our data support the idea that heme-induced phenotypic switching of macrophages toward a proinflammatory phenotype can contribute to the exacerbation of inflammation and chronic tissue injury in hemolytic disorders and that Hx therapy could alleviate these pathophysiologic consequences by preventing macrophage inflammatory activation.

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: Within cells, heme is catabolized by the activity of heme oxygenases (inducible HO-1 and constitutive HO-2) into iron, carbon monoxide, and biliverdin.

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: Importantly, protoporphyrin did not induce TNFα, suggesting a critical proinflammatory role for iron within the heme moiety (supplemental Figure 8).

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: Likewise, NAC was able to prevent iron-induced M1 polarization in M0, M1, and M2 BMDMs (supplemental Figure 13), indicating that the alteration of macrophage plasticity in response to iron is mostly explained by its pro-oxidant properties.

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: Recently, we demonstrated that Hx controls hepatic heme uptake and thus limits heme accumulation in extrahepatic tissues, such as the vessel wall and the heart, preventing heme-induced toxicity and tissue injury.

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: Taken together, these data demonstrate that Hx limits macrophage heme overload and prevents the prooxidant and proinflammatory effects triggered by heme in cellular assays and in vivo.

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: Taken together, these data demonstrate that Hx limits macrophage heme overload and prevents the prooxidant and proinflammatory effects triggered by heme in cellular assays and in vivo.

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: Taken together, these data demonstrate that Hx limits macrophage heme overload and prevents the prooxidant and proinflammatory effects triggered by heme in cellular assays and in vivo.

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: Treatment with Hx or DFO diminished the increase of some M1 polarization markers in BMDMs following treatment with hemolytic RBCs (supplemental Figure 14).

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: In addition, Hx and DFO prevented the heme- and ironmediated induction of the M1 markers MHCII, CD86, CD14, and TNFα and the decrease of some M2 markers, such as CD206, IL-10, and Arginase-1 (the last for FeNTA only) in M0 BMDMs (Figure 6A; supplemental Figure 15A).

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: Importantly, protoporphyrin did not induce TNFα, suggesting a critical proinflammatory role for iron within the heme moiety (supplemental Figure 8).

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: Taken together, these data suggest that Hx administration decreases heme-driven proinflammatory activation of macrophages.

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: In conclusion, an Hx-based therapy shows beneficial effects, in that it counteracts heme-induced proinflammatory activation of macrophages and attenuates some of its pathophysiologic consequences, such as chronic inflammation, hepatic fibrosis, and apoptosis (Figure 7E).

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: Our data support the idea that heme-induced phenotypic switching of macrophages toward a proinflammatory phenotype can contribute to the exacerbation of inflammation and chronic tissue injury in hemolytic disorders and that Hx therapy could alleviate these pathophysiologic consequences by preventing macrophage inflammatory activation.

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: Cotreatment of M0 BMDMs with heme and TAK-242 attenuated the increase of the M1 markers MHCII, CD14, TNFα, IL-6, IL-1β, and CD86 and the decrease of the M2 marker CD206, IL-10, and Ym1 in comparison with heme treatment alone ( Figure 4A; supplemental Figures 5 and 12).

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: Importantly, by scavenging free heme, Hx prevents heme-induced M1 macrophage polarization and thus avoids both TLR4 activation and ROS formation.

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: Our data support the idea that heme-induced phenotypic switching of macrophages toward a proinflammatory phenotype can contribute to the exacerbation of inflammation and chronic tissue injury in hemolytic disorders and that Hx therapy could alleviate these pathophysiologic consequences by preventing macrophage inflammatory activation.

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: Taken together, these data suggest that Hx administration decreases heme-driven proinflammatory activation of macrophages.

citation.name: Hemopexin therapy reverts heme-induced proinflammatory phenotypic switching of macrophages in a mouse model of sickle cell disease.

links.evidence: In conclusion, an Hx-based therapy shows beneficial effects, in that it counteracts heme-induced proinflammatory activation of macrophages and attenuates some of its pathophysiologic consequences, such as chronic inflammation, hepatic fibrosis, and apoptosis (Figure 7E).
